                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>

                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="author">author
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                    
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                            <gmd:organisationName>
                                <gco:CharacterString>North Saskatchewan Watershed Alliance</gco:CharacterString>
                            </gmd:organisationName>
                            <gmd:role>
                                <gmd:CI_RoleCode
                                        codeList="https://schemas.isotc211.org/19115/-3/cit/1.0/codelists.xml#CI_RoleCode"
                                        codeListValue="contributor">contributor
                                </gmd:CI_RoleCode>
                            </gmd:role>
                        </gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                    </gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                </gmd:CI_Citation>
            </gmd:citation>
            <gmd:abstract>
                <gco:CharacterString>Historic and published water quality data for the Vermilion River basin are limited; the intent of this project was to start updating a 20-year-old water quality database. The selection of water quality variables was suitable to describe general instream water quality conditions and identify issues potentially related to human activities. Surveys were only carried out during very low flow conditions, and stagnant water was often encountered. It should be noted that sampling during periods of higher flow would likely yield different results. Seven sampling locations were selected along the Vermilion River at key locations in the basin. Sites were located downstream of major urban centres (Vegreville, Mannville and Vermilion), hydrological features (Vermilion Lakes and the Morecambe structure), at the boundaries of counties and at the mouth of the Vermilion River. Several of the water quality sampling sites corresponded to sites sampled historically (1995 to 1997) although sites V1 and V4 were newly established in 2014. Four of the seven sites were located at or near an active Water Survey of Canada (WSC) gauging station. Sites on Stretton Creek were chosen upstream and downstream of a reach where efforts to protect and enhance riparian health are ongoing. This project was intended to provide historical data to evaluate the influence of ongoing riparian protection measures on stream water quality. Three longitudinal surveys were carried out during July, August, and October in 2014 to document water quality at low flow. Sampling encompassed a broad range of physical, chemical, and biological measurements designed to describe general instream water quality conditions, identify issues potentially related to human activities (e.g., nutrient enrichment, bacterial and pesticide contamination) and identify reaches with possible groundwater input.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:abstract>
            <gmd:credit gco:nilReason="missing"/>

            <gmd:status>
                <gmd:MD_ProgressCode

            </gmd:language>

            </gmd:topicCategory>

                            </gmd:extentTypeCode>

                            </gmd:westBoundLongitude>

                            </gmd:eastBoundLongitude>

                        </gmd:EX_GeographicBoundingBox>
                    </gmd:geographicElement>
                    <gmd:temporalElement>
                        <gmd:EX_TemporalExtent>
                            <gmd:extent>
                                <gml:TimePeriod gml:id="TimePeriod">
                                    <gml:description>seconds</gml:description>
                                    <gml:beginPosition>2014-07-07T11:15:00+00:00</gml:beginPosition>

name: 10-25976-3sh4-7n74
notes: Historic and published water quality data for the Vermilion River basin are limited; the intent of this project was to start updating a 20-year-old water quality database. The selection of water quality variables was suitable to describe general instream water quality conditions and identify issues potentially related to human activities. Surveys were only carried out during very low flow conditions, and stagnant water was often encountered. It should be noted that sampling during periods of higher flow would likely yield different results. Seven sampling locations were selected along the Vermilion River at key locations in the basin. Sites were located downstream of major urban centres (Vegreville, Mannville and Vermilion), hydrological features (Vermilion Lakes and the Morecambe structure), at the boundaries of counties and at the mouth of the Vermilion River. Several of the water quality sampling sites corresponded to sites sampled historically (1995 to 1997) although sites V1 and V4 were newly established in 2014. Four of the seven sites were located at or near an active Water Survey of Canada (WSC) gauging station. Sites on Stretton Creek were chosen upstream and downstream of a reach where efforts to protect and enhance riparian health are ongoing. This project was intended to provide historical data to evaluate the influence of ongoing riparian protection measures on stream water quality. Three longitudinal surveys were carried out during July, August, and October in 2014 to document water quality at low flow. Sampling encompassed a broad range of physical, chemical, and biological measurements designed to describe general instream water quality conditions, identify issues potentially related to human activities (e.g., nutrient enrichment, bacterial and pesticide contamination) and identify reaches with possible groundwater input.

notes_translated.en: Historic and published water quality data for the Vermilion River basin are limited; the intent of this project was to start updating a 20-year-old water quality database. The selection of water quality variables was suitable to describe general instream water quality conditions and identify issues potentially related to human activities. Surveys were only carried out during very low flow conditions, and stagnant water was often encountered. It should be noted that sampling during periods of higher flow would likely yield different results. Seven sampling locations were selected along the Vermilion River at key locations in the basin. Sites were located downstream of major urban centres (Vegreville, Mannville and Vermilion), hydrological features (Vermilion Lakes and the Morecambe structure), at the boundaries of counties and at the mouth of the Vermilion River. Several of the water quality sampling sites corresponded to sites sampled historically (1995 to 1997) although sites V1 and V4 were newly established in 2014. Four of the seven sites were located at or near an active Water Survey of Canada (WSC) gauging station. Sites on Stretton Creek were chosen upstream and downstream of a reach where efforts to protect and enhance riparian health are ongoing. This project was intended to provide historical data to evaluate the influence of ongoing riparian protection measures on stream water quality. Three longitudinal surveys were carried out during July, August, and October in 2014 to document water quality at low flow. Sampling encompassed a broad range of physical, chemical, and biological measurements designed to describe general instream water quality conditions, identify issues potentially related to human activities (e.g., nutrient enrichment, bacterial and pesticide contamination) and identify reaches with possible groundwater input.
notes_translated.fr: Les données historiques et publiées sur la qualité de l'eau pour le bassin de la rivière Vermilion sont limitées ; l'objectif de ce projet était de commencer à mettre à jour une base de données sur la qualité de l'eau vieille de 20 ans. La sélection des variables de qualité de l'eau était appropriée pour décrire les conditions générales de qualité de l'eau dans les cours d'eau et identifier les problèmes potentiellement liés aux activités humaines. Les relevés n'ont été effectués que dans des conditions de très faible débit, et de l'eau stagnante a souvent été rencontrée. Il convient de noter que l'échantillonnage effectué pendant les périodes de débit élevé donnerait probablement des résultats différents. Sept sites d'échantillonnage ont été sélectionnés le long de la rivière Vermilion à des endroits clés du bassin. Les sites étaient situés en aval des principaux centres urbains (Vegreville, Mannville et Vermilion), des caractéristiques hydrologiques (lacs Vermilion et structure de Morecambe), à la limite des comtés et à l'embouchure de la rivière Vermilion. Plusieurs des sites d'échantillonnage de la qualité de l'eau correspondaient à des sites échantillonnés par le passé (1995 à 1997), bien que les sites V1 et V4 aient été récemment créés en 2014. Quatre des sept sites étaient situés à proximité d'une station de jaugeage active des Relevés hydrologiques du Canada (WSC). Les sites du ruisseau Stretton ont été choisis en amont et en aval d'un tronçon où les efforts visant à protéger et à améliorer la santé des riverains se poursuivent. Ce projet visait à fournir des données historiques pour évaluer l'influence des mesures de protection des zones riveraines en cours sur la qualité de l'eau des cours d'eau. Trois enquêtes longitudinales ont été réalisées en juillet, août et octobre 2014 pour documenter la qualité de l'eau à faible débit. L'échantillonnage comprenait un large éventail de mesures physiques, chimiques et biologiques conçues pour décrire les conditions générales de qualité de l'eau dans les cours d'eau, identifier les problèmes potentiellement liés aux activités humaines (par exemple, enrichissement en nutriments, contamination bactérienne et pesticide) et identifier les tronçons susceptibles d'être alimentés par des eaux souterraines.

notes_translation_method.fr: Description text translated using the Amazon translate service / texte traduit à l'aide du service Amazon translate

description_translated.en: DataStream is an open access platform for sharing water and sediment quality data.
description_translated.fr: DataStream est une plateforme en libre accès pour partager des données sur la qualité de l'eau et des sédiments.

title: Vermilion River and Stretton Creek Water Quality at Low Flow

title_translated.fr: Qualité de l'eau de la rivière Vermilion et du ruisseau Stretton à faible débit
